PositionHistory.Title: Major Advisor (Director)
PositionHistory.Description: Biological Sciences, UTEP (1987). Thesis: Geographic Variation in the Zone of Contact between Two Subspecies of Gopher Snakes (Pituophis melanoleucus). PhD, University of Kansas, 1996. Presently, herpetology curator, American Museum of Natural History. Co-Director with R. G. Webb. 2. Christopher R. Harrison: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (1992). Thesis: A Taxonomic Revision of the Snakes in the Coniophanes piceivvittis species group. Presently, Instructor, San Antonio Community College. Co-Director with R. G. Webb. 3. Travis J. LaDuc: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (1996). Thesis: A Taxonomic Revision of the Adelphicos quadravirgatum species group (Serpentes: Colubridae). PhD, University of Texas at Austin, 2003. Presently, Assistant Curator of Herpetology, Texas Memorial Museum, University of Texas at Austin. Co-Director with R. G. Webb. 4. Curtis M. Eckerman: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (1996). Thesis: Variation, Systematics, and Interspecific Position of Heterodon nasicus (Serpentes: Colubridae). Presently, Science Group Chair/Arts and Sciences, Biology, Des Moines Area Community College. Co-Director with E. Walsh. 5. Alvaro Dominguez: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2000). Thesis: An Analysis of Rock Rattlesnakes (Crotalus Lepidus) from the Northern Portion of its Range. Presently, DOA agent in El Paso, Texas. Co-Director with R. G. Webb. 6. Paul E. Hotchkin: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2002). Thesis: Comparative Escape Behavior of Parthenogenetic and Gonochoristic Lizards of the Genus Cnemidophorus. Rated Top Graduating MS student in Biology Department, spring 2002. Presently, PhD program, UTEP. 7. Allison Davis: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2003). Thesis: The Limnology and Macroinvertebrates of Squaw Spring, Indio Mountain Research Station. Rated Top Graduating MS Student in Biology Department, spring 2003. Presently, Ph.D. Candidate, University of North Texas. 8. Vicente Mata-Silva: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2005). Thesis: Diet Comparison Between Sympatric Lizards of the Genus Aspidoscelis on Indio Mountains Research Station, Texas. Rated best MS thesis in Biology for 2005. Presently, PhD program, UTEP. 9. Luis Miranda: MS Biological Sciences (2009). Thesis: Ecological Analysis of Oxygen Consumption in Three Species of Rattlesnakes (Crotalus lepidus, C. molossus, and C. atrox) from the Northern Chihuahuan Desert of Trans-Pecos, Texas. Presently, PhD program, New Mexico State University (fall, 2009). 10. Hector Riveroll, Jr.: PhD Candidate, UTEP Biological Sciences (2002, In Progress). Dissertation: Phylogeography of the Rock Rattlesnake, Crotalus lepidus. Co-Director with Elizabeth Walsh. 11. Paul Hotchkin: PhD Candidate, Biological Sciences (2005, In Progress). Dissertation: Vegetation Change in the Franklin Mountains of El Paso, Texas. Co-Director with Craig Tweedie. 12. Vicente Mata-Silva: PhD Candidate, Biological Sciences (2005, In Progress). Dissertation: Spatial Ecology of Crotalus lepidus in the Northern Chihuahuan Desert. 13. Arturo Rocha: MS Biological Sciences (2009, In Progress). Spatial Ecology of the Trans-Pecos Rat Snake, Bogertophis subocularis, in the Chihuahuan Desert of Trans-Pecos, Texas. 14. Michael Lukefahr: MS Biological Sciences (2010, In Progress). Ectoparasite Comparison Between syntopic Unisexual and Bisexual whiptail lizards in the Northern Chihuahuan Desert of Trans-Pecos, Texas. 15. Ross Couvillon: MS Biological Sciences (2010, In Progress). Ecogeographic Analysis of the Herpetofauna of Indio Mountains Research Station, Hudspeth County, Texas. Committee Member 1. Christine Carranza: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (1997). Thesis: Parasites of the Lizards in the Genus Cnemidophorus Collected in West Texas and Southern New Mexico. 2. Deborah J. Gordon: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (1997). Thesis: Incremental Tail Loss and Running Speed of Cnemidophorus inornatus (Reptilia: Teiidae). 3. Brian J. Wooldridge: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (1999). Thesis: DNA Analysis for Metalloproteninase and Mojave Toxin Genes in Chromosomal DNA of the Mojave Rattlesnake Crotalus scutulatus. 4. Dominic I. Lannutti: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2000). Thesis: Morphological Variation in Salvadora grahamiae and Related Taxa (Serpentes: Colubridae). Instructor, El Paso Community College. Presently, PhD Program, UTEP. 5. Matthew McMillan: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2002). Thesis: Variation in Crotalus basiliscus and Crotalus molossus with an Evaluation of Hybridization. Presently, Ecologist SWCA Environmental Consultants, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 6. Raul Gutierrez: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2002). Thesis: Molecular Systematics of Proboscidae (Martyniaceae) and Allied Genera Using the ITS Region of Nuclear Ribosomal DNA. Presently, PhD Program, Arizona State University. 7. Francisco Martinez-Gonzales: PhD Environmental Sciences and Engineering, UTEP (2002). Dissertation: How Slope, Aspect, and Shading Angles Determine the Distribution of Some Plants in the Chihuahuan Desert. 8. Saul Nava: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2004). Thesis: Comparative Ecology Between Three Species of Geckos on Puerto Rico. PhD, Indiana Univ., 2009. Presently, Post-Doc at Harvard. 9. Helen Brewer: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2004). Thesis: A Survey of the Mammals of Indio Mountains Research Station. Presently, High School Teacher, Socorro ISD, El Paso, Texas. 10. Bonnie Payan: MS Secondary Education, UTEP (2005). Thesis: Affects of Inquiry Based Instruction. 11. Dana Carciumaru: PhD Geological Sciences, UTEP (2005). Dissertation: Structural Geology, Tectonics, and Fluid Flow in the Northern Bend of the Chihuahuan Trough. 12. Angela Chavez: MS Biological Sciences, UTEP (2006). Thesis: Comparative Vertebral Morphology in Medium-sized North American Artiodactyla. Presently, PhD program, UTEP (on leave of absence).

PositionHistory.Description: Thesis: Stratigraphic heterogeneities on dune Architecture and Fluid Migration, Permian Cedar Mesa Sandstone, SE Utah. 14. Joseph D. DiBenedetto: PhD Geological Sciences, UTEP (2008). Dissertation: Comparison of Oxygen 18/16 Ratio in Fossil Turtle Shells from the "Turtle-Oreodon Zone" (Badlands National Park, South Dakota) and Marfa, Texas (Little Egypt Local Fauna): Paleoclimatological Implications for the Mid Oligocene Temperature Fluctuations.

PositionHistory.Title: Geological Sciences
PositionHistory.Description: Thesis: Tectonic Geomorphology of Puna-Tsang Chhu Watershed, Bhutan. 16. John Enriquez: MS Chemistry, UTEP (2010): Thesis: Enthalpies of Mixing Water and Alkoxythanois. 17. Dominic Lannutti: PhD Candidate, Biological Sciences, UTEP (2004, In Progress). Phylogeography of the Mojave Rattlesnake, Crotalus scutulatus. 18. David Linn: PhD Candidate, Biological Sciences, UTEP (2005, In Progress). Quantification of Dacade-Time Scale Change in Land Cover and Radiative Forcing Potential in Beringia. 19. Rebeca Marin: PhD Candidate, Biological Sciences, UTEP (2005, In Progress). Dissertation: Assessing Land Cover Change at the Indio Mountains Research Station. 20. Angela Chavez: PhD Biological Sciences, UTEP (2008, Leave of Absence 2010). 21. Seth Page: PhD Geological Sciences, UTEP (2009, In Progress). Dissertation: Understanding and Reconstruction of Duplex Faulting of the Indio Mountains Using Balanced Cross Sections. 22. Pawan Budhathoki: PhD Geological Sciences, UTEP (2009, In Progress). Dissertation: Syntectonic Sedimentation in an Extended Basin, Cretaceous of Southern North America. 23. Fernanda De La Cerda: MS Environmental Sciences, UTEP (2009, In Progress). Thesis: Effect of Rain Events on the Seasonal and Permanent Water Bodies of Indio Mountains Research Station.

PositionHistory.Title: SENIOR HONORS THESES CHAIRED, COMMITTEE MEMBER
PositionHistory.Description: Survey of the Rodents of the Indio Mountains Research Station, Hudspeth County, Texas. Biological Sciences, UTEP (Chairman). Winner of the UTEP best honors thesis competition for 2002. Natalie Whitfield. 2002. Sporozoite Penetration in Mus mucsculus: Eimeria papillata and Eimeria falciformis. Biological Sciences, UTEP (Committee Member). Jennifer Ramos-Chavez. 2010. Genetic Variation Within Populations of the Bdelloid Rotifer Philodina megalotrocha. Biological Sciences, UTEP (Committee Member). COLLEGE COURSES AND ACTIVITIES DEVELOPED GENETICS AND EVOLUTION: Developed one semester graduate course for Masters of Art in Teaching program, UTEP (2009). ECOLOGY OF DESERT ORGANISMS: Developed a one semester graduate course, with lab section, UTEP (2005). DESERT ECOLOGY: Developed one semester upper division undergraduate course with a laboratory section, UTEP (2005). ENVIRONMENTAL BIOLOGY: Developed a one semester PhD level course for Environmental Science and Engineering Ph.D. program. UTEP (2004) FIELD BIOLOGY: Developed a one semester upper division undergraduate course that includes a weeklong field trip to Indio Mountains Research Station, UTEP (2000). INTERDISCIPLINARY SCIENCE: Co-developed a two semester, team-taught undergraduate course covering the history, major revolutions, and cultural implications of science, UTEP/EPCC (NSF funded). ZOOLOGY: Developed lecture courses in invertebrate (EPCC) and vertebrate zoology (UTEP and EPCC), plus respective labs. BOTANY: Developed a course in General Botany with respective lab (EPCC).

Natural History. Rena humilis (Western Blind Snake). Predation by Antrozous pallidus. Herpetol. Rev. RESEARCH IN PROGRESS Systematic Studies: Systematics of Trimorphodon vilkinsonii (protected Chihuahuan Desert colubrid snake) systematics of Crotalus lepidus (Chihuahuan/Sonoran Desert rattlesnake) systematics of Stenorrhina freminvillii and S. degenhardtii (Mesoamerican colubrid snakes). Ecological Studies: Population structure and dynamics of five species of teiid lizards, three species of iquanid lizards, two species of skinks, one gecko species, and three species of rattlesnakes. This research is primarily being done at Indio Mountains Research Center. Biogeography and conservation of Mesoamerican ecosystems, especially tropical vegetation formations and inclusive herpetofaunas. Biochemical Studies: Immunological analysis of the venoms and DNA analysis of red blood cells of three species of rattlesnakes. The majority of this research is being conducted at Indio Mountains Research Station and labs at UTEP. Biogeographic Studies: Biogeographic analysis of the herpetofauna of the Chihuahuan Desert and adjacent areas. Biogeographic analysis of the Mesoamerican herpetofauna. A book on the herpetofauna of Tabasco, Mexico, with Rosario Barragan, Univ. Autonomous de Tabasco. NON-PROFESSIONAL AND CIVIC ACTIVITIES

Achievement.Description: BIOLOGY: Developed a scientific research honors component for General Biology Human Ecology and Invertebrate and Vertebrate Zoology courses (EPCC). The honors components were field oriented research projects STUDENT RESEARCH: Developed and initiated extensive field research components into General Biology Zoology and Human Ecology courses at EPCC and Field Biology at UTEP. Students participated on one-week field trips to either The Center for the Study of Deserts and Oceans Puerto Penasco Mexico (fall) or to the Indio Mountains Research Station Hudspeth County Texas (fall spring summer)

Field Research biochemical analysis of rattlesnake venoms using immunological techniques snake and lizard ecology and Biogeography of Chihuahuan Desert Herpetofauna. All research projects include EPCC or UTEP undergraduate and graduate students.

Field Research in Mexico. A total of more than 20 man-months have been spent collecting and studying amphibians and reptiles in Mexico which supported two graduate degrees and ongoing professional research. Mexican states where fieldwork took place included: Chiapas Quintana Roo Yucatan Campeche
